channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Car Bomb Kills 7 Turkish Police Officers in Diyarbakir
item.description: About two dozen people were wounded in the latest violence to hit the biggest city in the largely Kurdish region of southeastern Turkey.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Thursday’s attack in Diyarbakir, Turkey, targeted a minibus carrying members of the police special forces.

item.title: Kosher Kilts and Plaid Skullcaps: Scotland’s Jews Get a Tartan
item.description: Rabbi Mendel Jacobs has drawn a wave of attention for his “Jewish Tartan,” a combination of colors from the Scottish saltire flag and the Israeli one.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Starwood Hotels’ Chinese Suitor Backs Out of Bidding
item.description: A consortium led by the Anbang Insurance Group of China withdrew its $14 billion offer with no explanation, clearing the way for Marriott’s offer.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and LESLIE PICKER
item.media:description: The W hotel in Los Angeles is owned by Starwood Hotels & Resorts.

item.title: Uganda’s Supreme Court Rejects Challenge to Presidential Election
item.description: The challenge by the third-place finisher, Amama Mbabazi, argued that President Yoweri Museveni was not validly elected and that false results had been disseminated.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Vojislav Seselj, Serbian Nationalist, Is Acquitted of War Crimes by Hague Tribunal
item.description: The decision by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia prompted a wave of outrage across the Balkans.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Imre Kertesz, Nobel Laureate Who Survived Holocaust, Dies at 86
item.description: What set the Hungarian writer apart from others was his insistence on describing Auschwitz and Buchenwald without outrage, especially in his definitive work, “Fateless.”
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN KANDELL

item.title: World Briefing: Cameron Rules Out Nationalization of Britain’s Struggling Steel Industry
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron spoke after Tata Steel, an Indian company, announced on Wednesday that it would seek to sell its British steel factories.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Investigators Pursue Leads on Frenchman Accused of Terror Plot
item.description: Reda Kriket, 34, previously convicted of robbery and acts of violence, had amassed an arsenal of weapons and bombs, and on Wednesday he was charged with terrorist conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Soldiers searched a wooded area on Thursday in the Marke district of Kortrijk, Belgium.

item.title: Gilles Laurent, a Filmmaker With an Eye for Sounds, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Mr. Laurent, 46, had such an intimate connection with the noises of everyday life that his collaborators say he “looked” at sounds as if observing an object.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: U.N. Peacekeeping Hit by New Allegations of ‘Sickening’ Sex Abuse
item.description: The allegations, if confirmed, would expand the scope of the sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers deployed in the Central African Republic.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Leaders Meet With Obama to Curb Nuclear Threat
item.description: Leaders from more than 50 countries gathered in Washington for the fourth, and possibly last, Nuclear Security Summit. The atmosphere was subdued.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama met with President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, left, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on the sidelines of the nuclear security summit on Thursday in Washington.

item.title: Jacob Zuma’s Home Improvements Violated South Africa’s Constitution, Court Finds
item.description: The country’s highest court ruled unanimously that the president flouted laws by refusing to pay back public funds used for upgrades including a pool and chicken coop.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Jacob G. Zuma answering questions in Parliament in March.

item.title: Zaha Hadid, Groundbreaking Architect, Dies at 65
item.description: Ms. Hadid, the first woman to win the Pritzker Prize, was renowned for her theoretical work that left a mark on skylines around the world.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Steve Forrest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zaha Hadid in her London apartment in 2008.

item.title: Brussels Attacks Renew Criticism of Security at Europe’s Airports
item.description: A police union leader and officers working at Brussels Airport expressed concern about lax security and baggage handlers with criminal records.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A security checkpoint at Brussels Airport in 2014.

item.title: ISIS Turns Saudis Against the Kingdom, and Families Against Their Own
item.description: Adopting elements of a Sunni creed known as Wahhabism, the Islamic State has recruited Saudis to kill their own relatives and to bomb mosques.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mishari al-Rashidi, whose foster brother, Sgt. Bader al-Rashidi, was killed by six of his own cousins who had joined the Islamic State.

item.title: Love Story? Ex-Wife Calls EgyptAir Hijacker Abusive
item.description: Marina Paraschos, who divorced Seif Eldin Mustafa 25 years ago, said he was “dangerous and unpredictable.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREAS RIRIS and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The police escorted Seif Eldin Mustafa from court in Larnaca, Cyprus, on Wednesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: To Unify Europe, Face the Mideast as One
item.description: It’s time for a comprehensive compromise, and Germany should set the example.
item.dc:creator: NORBERT ROTTGEN

item.title: Kolkata Overpass Collapse Kills 18
item.description: Rescuers were straining to save people believed to be trapped under the structure, which was only partly finished in a project years behind schedule.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Letter From Europe: Playing On Despite the Fear of Terrorism
item.description: An exhibition soccer match between Germany and England was a symbol of defiance after the attacks in Brussels.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Security officers at the Olympic Stadium in Berlin on Saturday during a soccer match between Germany and England.

item.title: Seoul Journal: Seoul Celebrates the Home of an American Hero
item.description: The home of Albert Wilder Taylor, an American journalist hailed in South Korea for breaking the news of the 1919 revolt against the Japanese, is being restored for the centennial.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The house in Seoul, South Korea, known as Dilkusha. It has been occupied by squatters for decades, but there are now plans to renovate it as a museum.
